subject: Re: [junit] Running Only Testable classes with Ant/JUnit task
messageBody:
Perhaps something like:

<junit>
<batchtest>
<fileset dir="${src.tests}">
<include name="**/*Test*.java"/>
<not>
<contains text="abstract class" casesensitive="yes"/>
</not>
</fileset>
</batchtest>
</junit>

would do the trick. This is my first stab at this and I have not run it...
On 11/7/05, cliftonccraig <cliftonccraig@...> wrote:

> Hello,
>
> This may sound like more of a novice question but I need to know what
> the best practice is for running all of my tests and ONLY my testable
> classes with the Ant Junit task. What I mean is this. I tried using
> the batchtest task which is severely limited. It only does a directory
> scan over my test source to pick up the test classes. The problem is
> sometimes I may include abstract classes under that umbrella for
> conveniece methods and they get picked up too. Also there is no
> garauntee that the source and class files will be one for one. (Eg.
> nested classes would go unnoticed as well as source files that
> don't/can't compile to a equivalent named class.) I would feel alot
> better if I could filter the .class files instead of the source and
> pull out only the classes that are TESTABLE. That is, classes that
> begin or end with "Test" and have at least one public no-arg method
> beginning with "test".
>
> So I plugged in DirectorySuiteBuilder from the junit addons project
> and added some custom code to accomplish this. My custom code, a class
> named DirectoryScannerSuiteBuilder, is included below. The problem
> with that approach, while it is a lot more accurate, is that the
> junitreport task now lumps all tests under my custom
> DirectoryScannerSuiteBuilder class name without separating out the
> detail. So my question is what would the best approach be? Should I
> stop being anal and just go with the batchtest approach and stop
> including abstracts under the test source directory? (Incedentally
> that's what I'm resoting to now.) Or is there a more elaborate
> solution sort of like a best of breed between the two approaches I've
> tried so far?
